awd_titl_txt: EFRI C3 SoRo: Programming Thermobiochemomechanical (TBCM) Multiplex Robot Gels
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to integrate sensing, computation, and actuation directly into the body structure of a micrometer- to millimeter-scale soft robot, by creating a new class of soft hydrogels that can be thermally and biochemically programmed. This integration is critical for constructing autonomous robots that can function in complex, real-world environments. This project seeks to develop a comprehensive framework for the design, programming, validation, and fabrication of these gel robots. The robots will respond to temperature and biochemical cues from the environment, make decisions, and execute multistep motion programs that will allow them to move in a desired direction. The project will address fundamental scientific and engineering challenges in hydrogel mechanics, biochemical sensing, path planning, and controls for continuum soft robots, making it possible to efficiently design and manufacture the hardware for gel robots and to program them with biochemical software. These robots will have potential applications in marine, biological and medical environments, including in vivo targeting and diagnostics in medical settings.  The project will also provide research opportunities to undergraduate and K-12 students, including those from underrepresented groups, via new and established outreach programs at Johns Hopkins University. 

The goal of this project is to develop a framework for building a broad class of submillimeter-scale thermobiochemomechanical (TBCM) C3 robots in the form of architected hydrogels in which systems of chemical sensors, actuators, and computing devices replace the electronic sensors, actuators, and controllers in traditional robots. The research objectives of the project are to develop thermal and DNA responsive hydrogels and utilize these materials with advanced patterning and printing techniques to assemble robots that can respond to TBCM cues which are of relevance to human environmental and physiological conditions. Hardware design will be guided by a biomolecular software framework, mechanics based computational and reduced-order control models to enable planning and sensory feedback control. The broader impacts of this work include K-12 outreach programs to foster participation in STEM, dissemination of the research in peer-reviewed journals, dissemination of code and data and the development of new educational materials for undergraduate and graduate instruction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Office of Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The funds supported the development of theoretical and experimental frameworks for creating temperature and biochemically programmable soft robots. A new class of gel crawlers was developed that can break symmetry and move unidirectionally based on contact forces. Unique DNA-based materials that integrate complex circuitry for autonomous function were created. Fabrication protocols using 3D printing or light-based patterning were developed for soft gels across size scales from the sub-mm to the centimeter. A new chemomechanical theory was developed for polyelectrolyte hydrogels that describe dynamic polymerization of polymer networks.  The approach was specified for the physically crosslinked hydrogel developed in previous works and applied to investigate the dependence of the swelling ratio on the ratio of DNA terminator to hairpin and the slow swelling kinetics. Experiments have shown that the swelling time for a DNA hydrogel segment was independent of its size.  The model showed that the increased fixed charge density of the polymerizing DNA crosslink excludes the DNA hairpins from the gel, which impedes further incorporation of DNA hairpins into the crosslinks.  The theory is also being applied to model the chemically crosslinked DNA hydrogels.  Finite element models were developed to design and control gel materials and robots. The finite element model of the multi-segment robot was applied to investigate the contribution of the swelling and deswelling kinetics and friction on locomotion. The results showed that friction was needed to break the symmetry of shape change to achieve a net translation of the robot, and the heating and cooling rates can be tuned to maximize the translation.  New methods for building low-order, data-driven models in real-time enable online gait optimization and steering control that is robust to robot damage. Methods to use DNA reactions to control robots autonomously were developed.   

These studies provide new knowledge on creating soft, untethered robots that can be programmed by biochemicals or temperature signals of broad relevance to biosensors, biomedical engineering, drug delivery, robotics, and medicine. Several PhD students were trained in micropatterning, 3D printing, soft robotics, materials characterization, and modeling. Also, MS, undergraduate, and school students, including those from underrepresented groups in engineering were trained in STEM fields. The results of the studies and research findings were disseminated via original research academic journal publications and presentations at local and national conferences. 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/13/2023
Modified by: David Gracias
